posts.cooked:
I recently switched over from android to an iphone 12.

previously android allowed me to go to privacy settings and enable BLOCK SCREENSHOTS.

on my iphone and updated signal app, i do not see that feature anywhere.

how do i block screenshots?

Looks like on iOS the screen security feature can only prevent the screen from being visible in the app switcher:

Signal Support

Screen Security

Use Screen Security to prevent Signal previews from appearing in the app switcher on your phone. This is unrelated to the screen lock designed to lock your Signal screen so that you can't interact ...

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked: On Android it is a client setting so the receiver can just disable it if he wants to make a screenshot. And even if it were not, on a rooted Android the “disable screenshot” option is easily circumvented. Even most banking apps here have given up and made it a setting.

managementfirm:

can we integrate this feature for ios

I don’t think iOS supports screenshot blocking, but the feature isn’t intended to prevent your contacts from taking screenshots; even the Android feature is a setting on your end and has no effect on your contacts.

The feature also doesn’t stop people from bypassing it with a modified client, rooted/jailbroken phone, with another camera, or simply by linking the official desktop client.

posts.name: Yoyo
posts.cooked:
Totally agree that 100% screenshot blocking isn’t technically feasible, but I think the conversation shouldn’t be just about whether it can be fully enforced — it should be about how much friction we can add to protect the average user.

WhatsApp already does this in specific cases (like blocking profile photo screenshots). It’s not bulletproof, but it creates a psychological deterrent. The typical “Okay, maybe I shouldn’t screenshot this.”

The key here is intentional design .

We’re not trying to stop someone with a rooted phone or a second camera — we’re trying to protect 95% of real-world users who wouldn’t even know how to bypass a basic block. And in doing so, we’re sending a clear message:

“This content is private. Respect it.”

It also builds trust in the product. Even if it’s not perfect, just giving users the ability to enable screen protection (like they do with disappearing messages) makes the experience feel more respectful and secure.

Allow users to activate something like “sensitive screen protection” either globally or per chat. When it’s on, block screenshots or show a message like WhatsApp does. Make it optional, but available.

It’s not about perfection. It’s about doing better than nothing.

iOS does not offer any way to block a screenshot. No app, neither Signal nor WhatsApp could block a screenshot - if people like it or not, that is the limitation.

BUT: An app can detect, when the user tries to make a screenshot.

What WhatsApp does here is pretty smart: They detect an attempt of the user to make a screenshot, and for a very short time, they replace the picture you were trying to capture (in your case: the profile picture) by a screen which says screen capture blocked.

So, iOS indeed MADE a screenshot.

Talking about iOS and WhatsApp, I do not see an easy way around this. Rooting the iPhone is currently no longer possible due to the lack of public jailbreak, and WhatsApp cannot easily be replaced by a modified version.

Signal could easily adopt this feature (for iOS only), and I do not really see any argument not to do it (so I agree with Yoyo),because the effort to implement this should be manageable. At least, I think so.

Only because a policeman could also be shot by a tank’s cannon, it will not stop him to use a bulletproof vest - this is not a false sense of security.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Did you just switch to AI text? Do note that AI generated content is generally not permitted outside of translation.

It’s maybe 25% effective if anything, not 95% of real world users. Unless you’re just trying to prevent the most basic urge to take a screenshot of your device. Anybody determined will find a way around this. I’d suspect maybe just 20% of users would be prevented from taking a screenshot with this methodology.

How would you choose to communicate this feature in an effort to indicate that it is not a technological protection? That’s the main issue to resolve here. Just like dissapearing messages, which Signal communicates as an organizational tool.

We’re trying to prevent security theater here, that is, a false sense of security that the content is completely protected, when not providing privacy guarantees like Signal’s cryptography typically does.

posts.name: Yoyo
posts.cooked:
Thanks, fair points.

And just to be clear, this wasn’t AI-generated. It’s me, taking a bit of time to give proper feedback, because I really believe in what Signal is building. I run a tech company myself, and I see this as something small that could actually bring extra value and help Signal stand out even more.

I get that it’s not a real security feature. It’s just a small nudge. Something that makes people think twice, like a subtle reminder — not a wall.

And I get the concern about “security theater.” But honestly, I think avoiding something just because someone might misread it seems like overkill. That’s where communication comes in.

If you’re clear with users — like you are with disappearing messages — you can totally make it work.

Maybe something like:

Screen protection mode

When enabled, Signal will try to block screenshots on supported platforms. This won’t stop other ways of capturing content and isn’t a privacy guarantee. It’s just a tool to encourage respectful communication.

Make it optional. Be clear. Let people decide.

It’s not about fake security. It’s about user intent and trust.

posts.name: Yoyo

Just to clarify my point one last time: try taking a screenshot of a WhatsApp profile photo. You’ll see it’s blocked. That’s exactly the kind of friction I’m referring to. No false promises, no guarantees — just a soft boundary.

I believe the same concept could apply to chats. Not for security, but out of respect and loyalty between users. A way to say: “Maybe think twice before capturing this.”

If it makes sense, great. If not, no problem at all. Just sharing the perspective.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Yeah, the only way I’d be satisfied personally would be if my mom read the warning and understood the implications. Something like: Disable Screenshot Support: This will request other users to disable native screenshot support within Signal for media and chats.

No words related to privacy protections, guarantees, preventing anything, etc. But I don’t feel like that’s realistic enough.

“soft boundary” is a great way of putting it. In our everyday day lives, we have all sorts of “soft boundaries” that can easily be skirted around, yet they are valuable and provide effective protection in different contexts.

for example, have you ever seen a gate at the end of a driveway that blocks only the driveway, yet there is no fence around the gate? someone can easily drive their car around the gate, but the gate is a “soft boundary” to prevent solicitors, or unwanted visitors from driving up to the house, although someone could get out of the car and walk to the house.

does that gate prevent everything? no. does it still work? yes. is it valuable even though it’s not the perfect, end-all solution? yes. should someone reject the idea of the gate because it doesn’t fix everything? No - that would be the Nirvana Fallacy.
